titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sala Udin Papers, 1980-2005 AIS.2006.01
titlestmt.author: Bryce R. Henry and Allyson K. Glazier.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:49:46 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Sala Udin, an activist and community organizer at local and national levels, served on Pittsburgh City Council from 1995-2005, representing Council District 6, which includes the Hill District, downtown Pittsburgh, and portions of the North Side and Oakland. The bulk of the materials in this collection document his time on city council and include subjects such as African-American and minority history, employment, and culture; Pittsburgh's financial crisis; and police accountability.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Allyson Glazier and Bryce Henry.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Sala Udin Papers, 1980-2005, AIS.2006.01, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Sala Udin Papers, 1980-2005, AIS.2006.01, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Sala Udin Papers are divided into 16 series:
Series I. Act 47 -- Municipalities Recovery Act / Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority (ICA)
Series II. August Wilson Center for African American Culture
Series III. Citizen's Police Review Board
Series IV. City, County, and State Files
Series VII. Mason Tillman Associates, Ltd.
Series XIII. Sala Udin Personal Files
Series XV. Women and Minority Business Enterprises

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Sala Udin, whose given name is Samuel Wesley Howze, was born on February 20, 1943 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to William and Mary Howze. Along with eleven siblings, he grew up in Pittsburgh's Hill District in public housing. He graduated from Port Richmond High School in New York in 1961 and soon after joined the Freedom Rider Movement in the South. In 1964, Udin registered voters for the Mississippi Freedom Summer Project and was active in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP), the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, Head Start Programs, and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

Throughout the mid-1970s Udin worked in social service agencies including as founder and Executive Director at the House of Crossroads, a drug treatment facility and the Multicultural Resource Training Center. He became politically active as a member of the Democratic Party. In 1995 he was appointed to the Pittsburgh City Council following the death of Councilmen Christopher Smith. Udin would later be elected to serve Council District 6 in 1997. District 6 includes the following neighborhoods: Allegheny Center, Allegheny West, Bedford Dwellings, Bluff, California-Kirkbride, Central Northside, Chateau, Crawford-Roberts, Downtown, Manchester, Middle Hill, North Shore, Perry Hilltop, South Oakland, Strip District, Terrace Village, Upper Hill, West Oakland. He was appointed by Mayor Tom Murphy to the Competitive Pittsburgh Task Force, which was commissioned to review the debt of the city caused by the rising cost of city services and to examine market driven options as possible solutions. Additionally, Udin served on the boards of the Housing Authority of the City of Pittsburgh and the Urban Redevelopment Authority.

As a member of City Council, Udin sponsored a referendum to create a jobs program called "Pittsburgh Works," leading to a petition drive to take his proposal straight to city residents. He also served on many committees, such as the Plan B Oversight Committee, which helped provide jobs for women and minorities, and the Disparity Study and Implementation Commission, which helped minority groups obtain jobs for the demolition of Three Rivers Stadium and the construction of Heinz Field and PNC Park. In both the 2000 and 2004 Presidential elections, he served as an elector representing the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. He served on council until 2005 when he was succeeded by Tonya Payne. The same year he lost his 29-year-old son, Patrice Amilcar Howze, to street violence in the Hill District on October 9, 2005.

Udin has also been active in theater. He starred as Becker in the August Wilson play Jitney in October 1982 at the Allegheny Repertory Theatre, and again in May 2008, as Holloway in August Wilson's play Two Training Running. He also starred in Wilson's plays Ma Rainey, Fences, and The Piano Lesson. In 1965, along with August Wilson and Rob Penny, Udin co-founded the Centre Avenue Poets' Theatre Workshop in the Hill District, Pittsburgh and the Black Horizon Theater in 1968. He was also involved in the founding of the August Wilson Center for African American Culture.
Since leaving public office, Udin has been serving as the president and CEO of the Coro Center for Civic Leadership's Pittsburgh chapter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Sala Udin Papers include materials related to the Pittsburgh Councilman's life and career. Subjects include Pittsburgh's financial crisis of 2003-2004 and its recovery process through Act 47 (The Municipalities Financial Recovery Act of 1987); African American employment and culture in Pittsburgh including the August Wilson Center for African American Culture and the International Center for African Music; the establishment and activities of the Citizen's Police Review Board; City, county, and state departments and activities; the Freedom Corner Memorial and civil rights history; Pittsburgh neighborhood development and organizational initiatives; the Pittsburgh Works job creation program; Plan B's creation of new stadiums; city planning and development materials relating to the Urban Redevelopment Authority; Women, minorities, and other disadvantaged business enterprises; and a variety of topical and personal files between the years 1980-2005.

controlaccess.corpname: Pennsylvania. Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority for Cities of the Second Class
August Wilson Center for African American Culture (Pittsburgh, Pa.)

did.unittitle: Act 47 - Municipalities Recovery Act / Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority (ICA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Act 47, or the Municipalities Financial Recovery Act, of 1987 empowers the Pennsylvania Department of Community and Economic Development to declare municipalities as financially distressed. Distressed municipalities are granted nonresident wage taxes and debt restructuring or adjustment in exchange for developing a recovery plan with an independent agency. The independent agency is able to make recommendations on the city's organizational structure, finances, and services.

In August 2003 the City of Pittsburgh laid off 446 employees, closed recreation centers and public pools, and eliminated various services. By February 2004 the city had its credit rating repeatedly downgraded, a cash shortfall threatening pension payments and payroll, and an independent audit calling into question Pittsburgh's ability to continue. In response Mayor Tom Murphy filed for distressed status in accordance with Act 47. Sala Udin and other city council members decided that despite the proposed cuts to city services and tax increases the financial recovery plan was necessary and voted to approve it. Since March of 2004 the City of Pittsburgh has worked with the Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority (ICA) and the Public Financial Management (PFM) Group to find solutions for its financial problems.

The Act 47 series includes correspondence and concerns from citizens, emergency response agencies, environmental services, unions, and other stakeholders directly impacted by Act 47; ICA memoranda, lawsuits, and reports; and recovery plans and proposed solutions. The folders are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series on the August Wilson Center contains materials related to the creation of the present-day August Wilson Center for African-American Culture. First called the African-American Cultural Facility, it later became the African-American Cultural Center of Greater Pittsburgh in 2002 and hosted a variety of cultural events before its renaming in 2006. Councilman Sala Udin served on its Board of Directors beginning in 2002 and remains (2011) an ex-officio member.

The series includes its initial bylaws, articles of incorporation, board and committee meeting minutes and reports, site plans and designs, business plans and studies, fundraising, newsletters, programs, and research subject files, including one on Charles "Teenie" Harris. Also includes materials regarding to the International Center for African Music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh Citizens Police Review Board (CPRB) is an independent agency created by voter referendum to investigate citizen complaints about improper police conduct. Sala Udin initially introduced the legislation to form the Board. After getting stuck in a series of debates and court challenges lasting nearly two years, Udin took the idea directly to the public and the legislation passed by public referendum. The referendum and its rules are governed by Title Six, Article VI of the City Code. The CPRB was based on a variety of similar models around the country including the CPRB in Philadelphia, materials of which are included in this series. The Board is comprised of seven members appointed by the Mayor and the City Council. The CPRB is limited to complaints regarding the City of Pittsburgh Bureau of Police and its officers.

The records in this series includes agendas and meeting files; agreements, ordinances, and resolutions between the CPRB, the City of Pittsburgh, and the Pittsburgh Bureau of Police; board member appointments and searches; citizens' complaints; correspondence; court document transcripts; reports on CPRB activities, police investigations and complaints; and research material related to establishing a police review board. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The series on City, County, and State Files includes materials related to the City of Pittsburgh, Allegheny County, and the State of Pennsylvania's cultural, political, and social activities during Sala Udin's tenure as city councilman. Subjects include authorities, agreements, assessments, charters, committees, correspondence, finances, minutes, municipal departments, reforms, reports, permits, and studies between 1994 and 2005. The series is broken into three subseries: Allegheny County, City of Pittsburgh, and Pennsylvania. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Allegheny County subseries is comprised of materials related to Allegheny County, Pennsylvania. Subjects include: property assessment and the Home Rule Charter.

did.unittitle: Home Rule Charter - Preparing Allegheny for 21st Century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The City of Pittsburgh subseries is comprised of materials related to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Subjects include: city council, city departments and authorities, employment, finances, housing, and taxes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pennsylvania subseries is comprised of materials related to the state of Pennsylvania. The materials in this series are primarily concerned with legilsature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series includes correspondence to and from Councilman Sala Udin and individuals, organizations, and companies locally and nationally between 1995 and 2005. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

did.unittitle: Association for the Study of African American Life and History
National Conference of Christians and Jews

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Freedom Corner series is comprised of materials related to the establishment of a monument at Centre Avenue and Crawford Street in the Hill District of Pittsburgh. The Freedom Corner was the former site of a billboard that depicted messages of opposition concerning a 1950s urban renewal plan to raze houses in the Hill District. It gradually became a rallying point for local marches and civil rights demonstrations. In 1992 the Hill District Project Area Committee sought to erect a sculpture at the site, but it would take until 2001, under the leadership of City Councilman Sala Udin, before Freedom Corner Monument was ultimately finished.

The Freedom Corner series includes construction and contract files; correspondence; design proposals for the monument; events and dedications; financial records; newspaper and press clippings; nominations and votes for people to be included on the monument both living and dead; photographs; promotional and educational publications; research related to Freedom Corner; and various Freedom Corner committees' documents, membership lists or directories, plans, and proposals. The series is broken down into ten subseries.

did.unittitle: Torch of Freedom Award Winners Marion Jordan and Monsignor Charles Owen Rice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In 1995 the Pittsburgh City Council formed the Disparity Study and Implementation Commission. The commission was charged to review how effective its M/WBE policies had been, to create new policy that could withstand potential legal challenges, and to encourage changes that could allow the city to further achieve its goals of eliminating discriminating in contracting. In 1999 the commission hired California-based Mason Tillman Associates (MTA) to conduct a series of disparity analyses regarding the success of W/MBE contracting done by the city. MTA examined service contracts awarded by the city and its five authorities between 1996 and 1998 to determine whether city contracts were utilizing minority and women contractors. The final report, of which the executive summary was written by Councilman Udin, found that no construction contract over $250,000 had been awarded to any W/MBE. Among other findings the MTA reports conclude that no architectural or engineering contracts had been awarded to minority businesses and describe a variety of general discriminatory conditions for W/MBE business owners including pressure for them to lower prices or increase their amount of work without raising their bid.
Materials in this series include the MTA's initial proposal to the City of Pittsburgh and its final report.

did.unittitle: City of Pittsburgh Contracting and Procurement Study Proposal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The City of Pittsburgh Contracting and Procurement Study Proposal is Mason Tillman Associates initial proposal addressed to Councilman Udin to conduct the Disparity Study and Implementation Commission's contracting disparity study.

scopecontent.p: City of Pittsburgh Contracting and Procurement Study Final Report is Mason Tillman Associates final report on contract disparity for women and minority businesses in Pittsburgh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Neighborhood Files series includes materials related to specific neighborhoods within Pittsburgh's District 6 or related to Sala Udin's general political interests, including the Hill District, Downtown, the Northside (including Manchester), Mt. Washington, Oakland, and the Strip District between the years 1987-2005. Subjects include: revitalization, development, housing, crime and public safety, and the Hill District Community Development Corporation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The District 6 subseries contains materials related to abandoned or condemned buildings existing throughout District 6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The neighborhood of Downtown resides within Councilman Udin's District 6. Subjects within this subseries include materials primarily on improving the livability of downtown Pittsburgh as well as its development and revitalization.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Pittsburgh Works series includes materials related to the City of Pittsburgh's local hiring ordinance. Pittsburgh Works was sponsored by Sala Udin and required that any construction contract using public money over $200,000 would employ 35% Pittsburgh residents and that any project entirely financed by the city would require 50%. Udin introduced the ordinance in 1998 primarily in response to jobs created by the $809 million Plan B stadium and convention center projects. The Works ordinance was approved by a referendum iniated by Udin and passed by city council in 2000. In 2001, the Pennsylvania State Senate amended Senate Bill 706 to prohibit the use of state funds on projects subject to municipal residency requirements thus severely limiting the effectiveness of the Pittsburgh Works ordinance.

Materials include bills and ordinances, legislation, meeting agendas and minutes, proposals, press release, reports, research data, statistics, and studies between 1996 and 2001. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Plan B series focuses on the Plan B controversy in Pittsburgh beginning in 1998. The Pittsburgh Steelers (NFL) and the Pittsburgh Pirates (MLB) shared Three Rivers Stadium. The "Plan B" proposal included building two new stadiums (Heinz Field and PNC Park) in addition to an expansion of the David L. Lawrence Convention Center. On July 9, 1998, the plan was approved by the Regional Authority Board for $809 million. Sala Udin was a chairman of the Plan B Oversight Committee which was able to provide several of the construction contracts to businesses owned by city residents, minorities, and women.

The Plan B series and the Women and Minority Business Enterprise (WMBE) series contain similar holdings because many jobs related to Plan B construction were performed by WMBE certified businesses. This series includes materials regarding Plan B to and from Councilman Sala Udin, the Chair of the Plan B Oversight committee. It includes documents surrounding the creation of the committee, correspondence to and from Pittsburgh citizens, organizations, and businesses, information about contracts, bids, and employment, news releases and articles, WMBE certification procedures for Plan B jobs, meeting minutes and agendas, agreements, project updates, Sports and Exhibition Authority documentation, statistics regarding minorities and women in Pennsylvania, and a petition for the reestablishment of magisterial districts. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Subject Files series includes materials from a variety of topical sources of interest to Sala Udin personally, politically, and professionally. Subjects include: individuals, organizations, locations, City Council photographs, programs, and Udin's time as a presidential electorate/DNC representative as well as his election and reelection materials. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Sala Udin Personal Files series includes personal records of Councilman Udin between 2001-2004, including phone bills, a biography, travel expense reports, certificates and honors, and material related to his part as George Miles in the theatrical production of "Off the Record."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Udin played George Miles, WQED's chief executive officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) was formed in 1946 and serves as the economic development agency for the City of Pittsburgh. It seeks to generate new jobs and increase the city's tax base to improve business and livability in neighborhoods. It is engaged in various urban renewal efforts including rehabilitation of housing, reclaiming brownfield and former industrial riverfront sites, and business development. The URA is also involved in promoting equal opportunities for minority and female owned businesses. All projects in excess of $250,000 must submit a Minority and Women-Owned Business Enterprise (M/WBE) Plan, which is then reviewed by the URA and the city's M/WBE Review Commission.

The Urban Redevelopment Authority series is comprised of accomplishment and goal reports; budgets and financial information; M/WBE compliance records; and neighborhood and business (re)development reports and project reviews. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order. This series is primarily comprised of materials recieved by Sala Udin in his capacity of city councilman and as a member on the URA's boad of directors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Women and Minority Business Enterprise (W/MBE) series is related to the Urban Redevelopment Authority series. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) supports diversity in all Pittsburgh area business. They require "all projects in excess of $250,000 to submit a Minority and Women-Owned Business Enterprise Plan, which is analyzed both internally and by the City's M/WBE Review Commission, to ensure success in this area. The URA expects all contracts of this size to achieve or exceed the goal of awarding 18% of the total project costs to MBE's and 7% of total project costs to WBE's."

The M/WBE series contains a history of the Minority/Women's Business Enterprise development program, participation plans and performance audits, correspondence to and from a variety of Pittsburgh area business, organizations, and individuals, conference materials, contract and plan review summaries, meeting memoranda, proposals, policies, and committee materials, and news coverage. Folders are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Audio/Visual Media series contains audiocassette tapes and VHS tapes related to legislative meetings, committee meetings, budget meetings, task force activities, public hearings, news segments, informational videos, and other public relations materials. The cassettes within the series include both sound and visual recordings of Sala Udin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Audio Cassettes subseries is comprised of cassette tapes of sound recordings.
